title: Week 1: Itâ€™s Alive - Bootstrapping the Simulated Mind
text:
â€œLife, although it may only be an accumulation of anguish, is dear to me, and I will defend it.â€ â€” Frankenstein



In our first week, weâ€™re focusing on building the bare-bones agent scaffold. This includes: - Basic movement capabilities - Environmental observation - Simple action loop - Logging system for debugging



### Agent ğŸ§…



Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.


AILO-style: A digital being thatâ€™s learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).



### Event Loop ğŸ§…



Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.


AILO-style: The agentâ€™s internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.



### Reflex Agent ğŸ§…



Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.


AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).

In Week 2, weâ€™ll be adding: - Long-term memory system - Time-stamped events - Memory retrieval strategies



Greetings, Earthling! Let me explain what we built this week in simple terms:
What We Built: A digital being that can move around and react to its environment. Think of it as a very simple robot that can walk and respond to basic commands.
Why It Matters: Before we can build complex AI that thinks and feels, we need to start with the basics. This is like teaching a baby to crawl before it can walk.
How to Explain It to Your Dog: Woof! (Translation: â€œItâ€™s like a new puppy learning to move its legs for the first time. Simple, but necessary!â€)
Stay tuned for more updates as we bring our first agent to life!

title: AILO Glossary
text:
Welcome to the AILO glossary, where we peel back the layers of AI terminology to reveal both the formal definitions and our more approachable AILO-style interpretations.





Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.
AILO-style: A digital being thatâ€™s learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).








Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.
AILO-style: The agentâ€™s internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.








Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.
AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).








Formal: A structured mental representation about the world held with some confidence.
AILO-style: A hunch the agent will probably act onâ€¦ even if itâ€™s wrong.


This glossary will grow as we add more layers to our simulated minds. Each term marked with ğŸ§… has both a formal definition and an AILO-style interpretation that makes it more approachable and fun.

title: AILO Blog
text:
Welcome to my blog, a storytelling-engineering journal that explores the strange, emotional, and sometimes unpredictable world of simulated intelligence. This blog documents the design of increasingly complex AI agents â€” not as models in a paper, but as characters in a world. You will hopefully see my successes, but more often you will see my failures.
Each post follows a weekly build cycle with:

title: AILO Blog
text:
Core Goal
To build agents that donâ€™t just work â€” they remember, feel, and change. This blog tracks that evolution, combining:

Research-inspired engineering
Weekly storytelling
Experimental system design

title: AILO Blog
text:
ğŸ“† Current Phase

Phase 1: Simulated Mind in a Game World
A 12-week experiment in designing agents that live, reflect, and grow inside a Stardew Valleyâ€“style sandbox. Each week introduces a new layer of mind â€” from walking to memory to personality drift.


ğŸ—ºï¸ Latest Progress

title: AILO Blog
text:
ğŸ§… What the Onion Means
Wherever you see this icon â†’ ğŸ§… That marks a layered word: something that needs peeling.
Hover over the onion icon after a word to see its layered meaning!
These terms will have: - The official definition - And my AILOcard-style version â€” honest, funny, and functional
Example: Belief ğŸ§…


Belief


Formal: A structured mental representation about the world held with some confidence.


AILO-style: A hunch the agent will probably act onâ€¦ even if itâ€™s wrong.



These definitions live in the glossary and appear in hover-tooltips throughout posts.

title: AILO Blog
text:
ğŸ‘½ Who Is the Martian?
Back in middle school, my Physics teacher told me the only way to understand something was to pretend you were explaining it to a man from Mars.
Iâ€™ve never forgotten that.
At the end of every post youâ€™ll find a Martian Mode ğŸ‘½. This is a plain-language TLDR written for someone from another world â€” or another field.
It breaks down: - What I built - Why it matters - How to explain it to your obtuse martian friend
Because interpretability isnâ€™t just for the models â€” itâ€™s for the humans, too.

title: AILO Blog
text:
Future Phases
This isnâ€™t just a one-off experiment. AILO unfolds across three interconnected phases:









Phase
Title
Focus
ğŸ‘½ Simple explanation




Phase 1
Simulated Mind in a Game World
Agents, memory, mood, identity (Unity-based)
How intelligence is made â€” like growing a brain one behavior at a time


Phase 2
LLM Debugger
Visual tooling for understanding how LLMs think
How intelligence thinks â€” and how to actually look inside its head


Phase 3
Quantum-Native Reasoning
Research into quantum-aligned reasoning systems
How intelligence can be redefined â€” with math that doesnâ€™t follow our rules

title: AILO Blog
text:
Why This Blog Exists
This isnâ€™t a devlog. Itâ€™s not a textbook. Itâ€™s a research-meets-narrative experiment â€” an engineering novel, one post at a time.
Youâ€™ll see code.
Youâ€™ll meet characters.
And youâ€™ll slowly forget whether the agent is simulating a mind â€” or you are.
